newsitem.title: VENEZUELA: Doctors' strike could lead to Venezuelan emergency.
newsitem.headline: Doctors' strike could lead to Venezuelan emergency.

text.p: The Venezuelan government said on Saturday it was considering declaring a national state of health emergency to deal with an eight-day public doctors' strike over pay.

The administration of President Rafael Caldera, facing its worst crisis in a public health system notoriously underfunded and poorly supplied, appointed a special ministerial team to try and solve the pay dispute with the country's 25,000 doctors.
"President Caldera is studying all options and a national emergency is one of them," a presidential spokeswoman said.
The measure would entail a militarization of Venezuela's 380 hospitals and 4,000 ambulance services.
The government has said it will not negotiate with the striking doctors until they returned to work, first at emergency wards nationwide.
Planning Minister Teodoro Petkoff, summing up the government's stance, said on Friday: "You cannot negotiate with people who put a revolver to the poor's heads."
The government is willing to grant a 25 percent increase in pay, in line with what is being planned for the whole public sector.
Venezuelan doctors, who earn a minimum $126 per month and $304 monthly average including bonuses, demand at least $735, down from an initial $1,000 when the stoppage began on Dec. 27.
Authorities said the strike has led to the deaths of 10 patients, who died for apparent lack of adequate medical treatment, and have threatened legal action.
